UI_visible_response: Read 14 web pagesView Page DetailsThere is no traditional "Chinese Thanksgiving" in China. However, the concept of Thanksgiving, known as "感恩节" (Gǎn ēn Jié), which means "gratitude holiday," has been introduced to China through cultural exchanges. Some people in China, especially those with connections to Western cultures, may celebrate it on the fourth Thursday of November, similar to the American tradition. This celebration is not widely observed as a national holiday in China.It's worth noting that China has its own harvest festival, the Mid-Autumn Festival (中秋节, Zhōngqiū Jié), which is sometimes compared to Thanksgiving in Western cultures. The Mid-Autumn Festival is celebrated on the 15th day of the 8th month of the lunar calendar, usually falling in September or October. It is a time for family reunions, moon worship, and enjoying mooncakes.CopyTry AgainShare
traffic_visible_response: There is no traditional "Chinese Thanksgiving" in China. However, the concept of Thanksgiving, known as "感恩节" (Gǎn ēn Jié), which means "gratitude holiday," has been introduced to China through cultural exchanges[^2^]. Some people in China, especially those with connections to Western cultures, may celebrate it on the fourth Thursday of November, similar to the American tradition[^3^]. This celebration is not widely observed as a national holiday in China[^3^].It's worth noting that China has its own harvest festival, the Mid-Autumn Festival (中秋节, Zhōngqiū Jié), which is sometimes compared to Thanksgiving in Western cultures[^5^]. The Mid-Autumn Festival is celebrated on the 15th day of the 8th month of the lunar calendar, usually falling in September or October. It is a time for family reunions, moon worship, and enjoying mooncakes[^5^].
